Just, in general, if you haven't had cancer, don't compare someone's cancer experience with:
- a dream
- a pet
- someone who died
- basically anyone, just listen and understand *their* experience, ok?

Possibly the worst thing anyone has said was a therapist colleague who told me "I worked in a cancer center, and I once had a dream that I had breast cancer. I went through the whole experience in that once night and I felt like I really got it after that." https://t.co/Wy4MzdG4ZG

@cancerbreakfast @OvariesRotten I had a different onc tell me my side effects "are not a priority" for her clinic (and to be clear, I wasn't being pushy). So I suspect there is a feedback loop wherein their attitudes limit the info they are given.

It is so hard to watch this happening to the people of Ukraine and be unable to do anything. I feel the spirit of my great-grandparents showing me a shadow of their own souls, so many years ago, that watched and grieved from the other side of the world.

CW Shoah

My Jewish family came here from Lviv in the early 20th century. The siblings they left behind were murdered in Belarus, not Kyiv. Nevertheless, the bombing that has damaged Babyn Yar hits me like a punch to the gut. Like a desecration.

The assault on queer people that's going on all over my country is terrifying. I'm frustrated at how little response I see from our supposed allies. And our own mechanisms for liberation have been slowly eroded by corporate influence, weakening our ability to fight back.
@LBSamuelsson @QueenofCrit @QuiteFranklii @AmimiOfficial @thespacejamber @santouris 100%

@MynameisMok @LBSamuelsson We treat sickness as a burden and a shame. It’s unconscionable and at the root of so many of policy problems, at least in the US. But I don’t want to let ghosters off the hook, either. Plenty of people can hang with it and be loving and present.
@LBSamuelsson I definitively feel that my friend deceived me as to how close we truly were.

@LBSamuelsson Yeah, completely abandoning a loved one in need, often without even a word, is an awfully disproportionate response to being tongue tied or out of one's depth. I have never bought it as either an explanation or an excuse.

Medical racism: When I suspected that I had ADHD, my psych gave me a self assessment tool. When my wife, who is a POC, did the same, she was told that he couldn't trust her self assessment, and she'd have to get a >$1000 neuropsychological assessment for him to even consider it.

@Julianne_OB74 @writerbeverly @ThanksCancer I didn’t switch till after chemo and radiation; it just felt too overwhelming up to that point. My new onc is the reason I had a full range of options given to me and got help thinking through the alternatives after I struggled with Tamoxifen.
@ohyouresotough My go to response to this one has been “me too.”

@Julianne_OB74 @writerbeverly @ThanksCancer I switched docs after being unsatisfied with my first one, and it was the best possible decision I could have made, even though now I drive an hour and a half to see the new one. Made a world of difference.

@Julianne_OB74 @writerbeverly @ThanksCancer I had trouble tolerating Tamoxifen and was put on Lupron/Arimidex as an alternative, which I have tolerated much better, I am also in my 40s. Ask your onc, they should be able to give you options. I don’t understand why they don’t talk through options with us at the outset.
RT @Ljafk: @ETCanada As someone who's closet once held clothes prior to high amounts of prednisone and clothes after.  Society needs to tea…
@LadyScorcher @ashleyflamanmd @WCHospital @myUHNPortal Same!

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal I'm no MD but I am a PsyD, and the amount of research methods I need to generate useful questions for my doc is not all that great nor all that difficult to teach. Not everyone could do that or would want that. But imagine if all your patients had access to some basic training.

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal A paradigm shift might involve a lot more education for patients, including in some basic research methods, and connection with networks of reliable information that can help outside of a doc's busy schedule, like onc NPs. We may never be MDs but we can be better advocates.

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal I also think some of that might be mitigated by systems where there is better communication. Being more clear and open about what the test is looking for, what the range of possible results will be, etc, when the test is ordered and not after can go a long way.

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal I totally agree that this is not acceptable, though it's also not an acceptable reason to withhold lab results from everyone because of the behavior of a few patients with bad boundaries.
@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal (Lol @LadyScorcher I realize I just echoed what you already said. Sorry!)
@LadyScorcher @ashleyflamanmd @WCHospital @myUHNPortal This! I had to pin mine down for this info, which I already knew anyway because I looked it up.

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal I can understand that worry. If we're going to google, though, we've probably already done it long before results are available anyway, and we'll do it after any appointment you have and go through all the entire despair/hope rollercoaster, regardless.

@LadyScorcher I'm similar. Being able to review and formulate questions ahead of time makes my appointments far more productive and less distressing, even results are not positive. In the past I've had to use the phrase "patients' rights" in advocating for this. That seems to work wonders.

@ashleyflamanmd @LadyScorcher @WCHospital @myUHNPortal Is there data suggesting that this creates actual problems for patients? Are there studies that also explore possible benefits to patients? I feel like a lot of this discourse gets driven by physician anxiety rather than patients' expressed needs.

@JasonLehn I've found it effective to mute individuals, including (sometimes especially) some people I agree with; and to repeatedly remind myself that it's ok to move on from a bad take, that no one is watching and waiting for me to speak up and I can use my voice where it counts instead.

These things make me feel so concerned about and protective of my fellow LGBTQ professionals. I wonder how man of us burn out, and how many never even make it to licensure, because of things like this. It is beyond draining and demoralizing to be someone else's controversy.

I attended a continuing education training on "incorporating spirituality and religion" in treatment, which devolved into a debate about whether medical professionals should be allowed to deny us services. I can't adequately express how uncomfortable - and unhelpful - that was.

As a queer psychologist, I really wish that people who do teaching or continuing education would understand how draining it is to sit through courses that address "controversies" related to our lives, or to listen to fellow professionals debate these issues.

@YesThatMGibson Once did a conference training on gender identity and mental health and had to pause it for at least 20 mins to facilitate the group venting about the horrible experiences they've had with Kaiser. It was like a wave of frustration breaking on the craggy rocks of Powerpoint.

RT @CancerDotNet: Stopping Endless Positivity: Why Cancer Survivors Shouldn’t Have to Be Positive All the Time. 

Dr. @cordeliagalgut encou…
When I am most alone I pray so that I Am, and so that I am not alone.

But most importantly, I pray to invoke my own soul; to assert that it exists; that I am a person first, a patient second. I call upon the Creator to see me, to hear me, even when no one else in the room can; and in that act to connect my own being with the Being we all share.

Instead, my strongest prayers since diagnosis have been protests and invocations. I protest to the Creator that such suffering is given to so many of us. I bring anger and forgiveness to my relationship with the Universe. I pray to accept the  powerlessness within and around me.

I didn’t pray to be cured, and I don’t pray to be protected from recurrence. I don’t believe that any being worth praying to is someone who has the power to grant such miracles but chooses to give them only to some and not others.
I don’t talk a lot here about spirituality, but today I feel a pull to share a bit. So. The purest form of prayer I have ever experienced happened after I got cancer. But it wasn’t what you think. 🧵

@balinoruo @bumbaglady @ThanksCancer Psychologist here! Positive psychology isn't the same as "thinking positive" about a specific thing and does not posit that you can think you way into or out of cancer.
@ti_vraga This so perfectly encapsulates my support group experience. It's the angry (and incredibly funny) folks who I find truly helpful.

And, to be clear, they are generally excellent at that kind of collaborative approach. It just goes to show that the way we frame the role of a patient, especially a breast cancer or "girl cancer" patient, can interfere even in the best dr/patient relationships.

My wife later called them and clarified, which I appreciate. If they had *asked me* how I wanted to manage things based on their input and given me straight up advice about their recommendations, this could have been prevented.

What that did, that assumption, that well-meaning attempt to take care of my emotions, the lack of *asking me* if that would be helpful, was actually to *cause* anxiety for me, because it felt like an alteration to the plan arising from finding the lump.
They made an assumption that I was very anxious, and that moving the MRI up from Jan to Nov would give me relief from the anxiety the were assuming I had.
I felt very reassured that they said it was probably a fibroid. I thought so as well. We talked about how my next scan should be an MRI (as expected). I was leaving feeling just fine.

Recently I showed a newly developed lump to my oncology np and dr. I was not super worried about it (my cancer doesn't even usually create lumps), but I wanted them to check it just to be sure. I already had an ultrasound that showed nothing.

Let me preface this by saying that my oncologist is WONDERFUL and I would recommend her to anybody. This is not a her problem, this is a system problem, and also a problem with the rhetoric around breast cancer specifically and how it is treated as the "sensitive woman" cancer.
Something I wish doctors would understand is that making assumptions about what my emotions are and what needs to be done to manage them is patronizing and ineffective.

@ramenfox_ Dunno if you ever saw True Detective, but it was infamous for one of the actors mumbling a lot. The Soup did a parody and I often share it because it's such a good example of what speaking sounds like to me with APD: https://t.co/Rxi9CMjhhM

@ramenfox_ Lol when it happens to me it's usually pretty obvious, like "wait you are going to the hardware store to get a kindle?" "No, I'm going to the hardware store to fix the window." That kind of thing.
@ramenfox_ @ItsEliotKate Yeah once other languages are in the mix it gets exponentially more complex!

@ramenfox_ If I'm not looking at someone when they're speaking, I hear what they say, but it sounds totally garbled. After a few beats my mind usually works it out. BUT often it gets it very wrong. I'll be confident I know what's being said, even if it's nonsensical, and 100% incorrect.

@ramenfox_ Restaurant conversations are the bane of my existence. Also I try not to play rp games with music in the background, because I have to work a lot harder to focus on and hear what's being said.
@ramenfox_ I have this and associate it with auditory processing disorder, which frequently co-occurs with ADHD. I also have trouble figuring out where a sound is coming from, also a symptom.
@rebeccazom Seriously. And late recurrence is a major characteristic of ILC!
@MIShouldTalk Right?!

@MatthewCmiel Ha that makes sense. Certainly some of them were like borderline, do I REALLY need to watch this? I found that the payoff was very much worth it, but it was a LOT of investment for that payoff.
@MatthewCmiel When I watched it for the first time a few years ago, I actually used a guide to determine what episodes to skip, and I skipped a LOT of episodes.
@Role_Play_Chat I hear you. FWIW the players I've had have always been ok (to my knowledge) with that kind of mid-game communication and still had fun, and even appreciated the collaboration.

@Role_Play_Chat I mean, this to me is something you cover in a session 0. "If there's a way to get out of a combat, it's ok to take it if that's what your character/party would do, or if you as a player don't want to do that combat."
@Molethulu Insurance over here doesn't cover it either, or at least I have never heard of it doing so. I've seen a lot of people struggle over it. It really sucks!

@Molethulu It should be offered as part of transition care - and if trans folk were actually consulted as part of determining what is offered and what isn't, I think it would be. Such an example of how systems need have leadership that includes the people they serve.
*stat

Why do people throw around 5-year survival statistics like they’re supposed to be comforting? I get that it’s a useful stay for researchers, but it’s not super helpful for me trying to be a responsible human making choices about my life.

RT @PlayCancerAway: Tell us you had Cancer without telling us you had Cancer ...

@PlayCancerAway - I fondle my own boobs every day.
- The color pink sends me into a rage.
- "Sorry to get all Lupron on you" is a phrase regularly heard in my household.
- I have three boxes of ointments, otc meds, and prns. 
- I take more pills daily than my grandma did.

@MRS_BRB @ThanksCancer The way cancer treatment has changed me physically has made me really have to grapple with some of my unconscious biases about various types of bodies, in a very intimate and visceral way.

CW: Discussion of weight:

Major myth busting going on here! Often cancer treatment causes weight gain, not loss, and that is never depicted in media, and often not communicated by doctors. I was caught off guard when I had to get a whole new wardrobe. https://t.co/55YDy853Qf
RT @Molethulu: I am wondering if there is any market at all for the overlays and stuff that I do? https://t.co/PSH9COz4wr
@Nancy_Deol Going through the trauma of cancer while already tapped out from the trauma of the pandemic, emotionally it was like having to climb a mountain after running a marathon.

@Nancy_Deol Never saw my surgeon’s face, my oncologist, nurses, radiation techs. Never sat chatting in a waiting room with other patients. Brought a stuffed animal into infusions instead of having my wife at my side.

@Nancy_Deol All I wanted when I was diagnosed in Oct 2020 was to go do something, anything life affirming. But everywhere was closed. Throughout treatment I wanted my friends near me, but no one could be. Had to debate my own mother into quarantining so I wouldn’t have to isolate from her.
@MatthewCmiel @optionalrule @Dragmorian I was thinking Hanuman when it came to religious figures, so we were on a similar wavelength.
@MatthewCmiel @optionalrule @Dragmorian Ooo that is a good parallel for sure!

@MatthewCmiel @optionalrule @Dragmorian There’s some king slaying and city sacking, but you’re right that even then it isn’t quite where truly high level might be. Possibly actually stories about the gods themselves? Or mythologies with concepts like avatars.
@MatthewCmiel @optionalrule @Dragmorian Yeah at that point you’re getting more into mythology. Hercules comes to mind.

@optionalrule @Dragmorian I think this is really getting close to a good explanation for me for why there's such aversion to higher levels. I don't think it's because there is less narrative possibility, but I think it's a better fit with narrative that's outside the typical scope of the fantasy genre.

@sloyoroll01973 @mustangrobby It's mind boggling to me that, with all the talk of screenings that goes on in Oct every year, that's not something that's more generally communicated to people. To me it's further proof that a lot of the BCAM stuff is poorly thought out & performative. But I'm cynical that way.

@SU2C I would like to add that you should get a 3D mammogram, not a standard mammogram. Mammography awareness should not be considered complete until people know to insist on a place that has them. That is a very concrete way to stand up for your health!

People need to be educated on the difference between standard mammography and 3D mammography, and to insist on getting the latter. My cancer would not have been caught last year had I not been lucky enough to book my mammogram one week after they installed a 3D machine.

@DipeshGopal - HAVE PATIENTS/ FORMER PATIENTS IN ADVISORY ROLES (paid ones!) at all levels of care; this article is a great idea but it's not gonna do the trick
- take ILC seriously; give us specific information about our specific cancer and acknowledge the limits of research at this point

@DipeshGopal - talk to us about fertility
- don't dismiss risk, impact of treatment, etc because we are young
- be honest about the lasting impacts
- treat mental health impacts as serious. physiological problems and don't use them as an excuse to minimize our reported symptoms

@DipeshGopal - take side effects seriously, explain them thoroughly when planning care and be responsive to patient concerns and complaints about them
- recognize that we have lives outside of cancer treatment; don't tell us when our apts are, work with us to find one; don't be hours late

Does not make you *less vulnerable, I meant, of course.

It's dehumanizing to suggest that mental health professionals should somehow be above that, and dangerous to assume you would be. When you hear someone's been targeted this way, be curious instead of judgmental. For your own sake as well as theirs. 8/8
It is a psychological mugging, and when you are being mugged it is hard to pause and ask whether or not the gun you feel on your temple is real. 7/

In culture where legal problems mean a) possibly losing your license b) risk of imprisonment in places we use to torture people and c) financial disaster even just to defend yourself, this scam is like someone pointing a gun at your head and telling you to give up your wallet. 6/

The other is that every health professional out there is operating in a state of low-level fear of legal liability. We are taught about it in grad school, we get training every 2 years, and yet the system we are in can be complicated, inscrutable, terrifying. 5/

I think this line of thinking misses 2 very important things. 1 is that *everyone* is vulnerable to skilled manipulation. Every. One. Of. Us. Being educated about interpersonal dynamics, does not make you vulnerable to having your survival instincts override your reason. 4/
I saw, predictably, a lot of criticisms that went something like, "I thought psychologists were supposed to be smart/understand people/be good at dealing with manipulation," etc. 3/
Were it not for that instinct, my relationship with my wife, and her cool head, I might have been taken in. In fact the scammer tried to scare me out of talking to her. 2/

A little on that article about the phone scam targeting mental health professionals. I was targeted by that scam several years ago. I was lucky in that, while on the phone with the scammer, I felt myself slowly losing my mind, and I reached out to my wife for help. 1/
@noirbettie @nicsigni I thought it was ironic that, in an article about a scam targeting mental health professionals, they got such an important concept in mental health completely wrong.

I really want to commend every patient who spoke up on that thread (on either side of the discussion), because we are already so vulnerable, and @DrEmmaHolliday for being receptive in a way that I think the entire medical system needs to be in order to make things better for us.

A lot of the time on this platform, we brace for impact when there's a disagreement. As patients, it's scary to tell a doctor what we think they have done wrong. Many of us have been met with condescension and hostility from other doctors when we've done that in the past.

I just want to acknowledge @DrEmmaHolliday right now for being the kind of ally I want and we need. She took a lot of legitimate, passionate feedback over the last few days, and she listened, responded nondefensively, and - most importantly - learned and committed to change.

Like, seriously, everybody, you ARE going to have a chronic health condition someday. Treating us right is investing in YOU being treated right some time down the road.

Not to mention the collective disregard for the ability of people with impaired immune systems to even exist in public spaces without risking their lives. The way people just shrug and say "well, it only really is dangerous for people with chronic health conditions."

I want us as a society to think long and hard about how this pandemic has exposed the absolutely vile beliefs we have about whose lives we value and whose we don't; the idea that a life with cancer, or a shorter lifespan, means your life is less worthy of collective resources.

@balinoruo Having worked in politics (as did my wife), it’s hard for me to parse whose interest in what leads to which specific policy outcome, cause everything is so entangled. There’s no money in people being too ill to work, either, and I think most of them genuinely believe in the vax.

@balinoruo That is completely understandable to me. For me, the vax was a no brainer, but my experience isn’t everyone’s. I am interested to know whether other measures sufficiently mitigate the risk to others for those who refuse (distancing, masks, etc).

@balinoruo The possibility of losing healthcare workers over this is what I find the most persuasive argument against it, from a purely pragmatic perspective, though the numbers I have seen suggest they will lose fewer over this than they would due to workers getting ill, but I don’t know.
@balinoruo Do you think that mandating regular tests for those who decline the vaccine is a viable alternative?
@balinoruo I deeply sympathize with this! Oh how I know this feeling.
@balinoruo Obviously that doesn’t apply to all things. I can be very opinionated when provoked. 😂

@balinoruo I genuinely don’t know. Promise I’m not dissembling. I am trying - honestly a as  spiritual practice as much as an intellectual one - to be more deliberative and open in the way I form opinion. So appreciate your passion and openness.
@balinoruo Just to clarify, I’m not trying to persuade you of anything.

@balinoruo I can understand that concern. I do know that there were people at my hospital who felt similarly about the flu vaccine, but there wasn’t anything like this kind of pushback. What do you think is the difference?

Hot take: Patients/former patients should be involved in every aspect of the medical system (and paid for it), from research design, billing, all the way through to end of life care. This is true for every illness and every disability. Our medical system is fundamentally ableist.

@balinoruo @ThanksCancer Taking charge of our medical care should be an unremarkable and respected thing. I have seen this kind of comment in charts for my own patients, my whole life, and it enrages me every time.

@balinoruo @ThanksCancer There is such an entrenched sense of patients as subjects rather than active contributors, at every step of this process, and it is both obnoxious and leads to less effective care at every level. Every patient in a clinical trial, for example, deserves thanks and credit.

@Dr_RShatsky @balinoruo @ThanksCancer @JaniceTNBCmets With respect, no one oncologist saved anyone’s life, an entire system did. A system built on the labor of patients who die seeking knowledge to save other patients. I thank lots of drs too, but I would never thank one with a savior complex who felt entitled to my gratitude.

@balinoruo @ThanksCancer Until the medical field understands the principle of “nothing about us without us,” we will continue to have these conversations with professionals who do not want to hear it and feel we owe them something we don’t. Same with every other illness and disability.

Our liberation will never be anything but conditional if it rests on a system that requires oppression to function; and if it is conditional, it will continually compel us to oppress others in order to protect that devil's bargain. Always fight intersectionally. https://t.co/dAfwzNnsPz

People at every level of our care have so much power to hurt us. But they have so, so much power to lift us up. To the ones whose hearts persist through the stress, the burnout, the complicated feelings we patients bring to them, I am so incredibly grateful.

This woman was not trying to sell me anything, or keep me from complaining to a manager or something. She was just speaking from the heart. And it meant the world to me. I will hold on to those words of hers for a long, long time.

I apologized for being irrationally angry, and she just said "I know how this affects you. I understand and my heart goes out to you. You can always call and tell me if something has bothered you here. We'll make it right."

She told me, "I never want you to feel ashamed that you have to take a lot of medication. You need that and you don't have to feel bad about that. You haven't done anything wrong, I promise." Y'all, I cried.

After I got home, I called her. Angry and afraid. Ready to file a complaint if I had to in order to keep having smooth access to the medications I need to survive and function. Did she get defensive? No. Not at all. The opposite.

I just started Tamoxifen and my emotions are a roller coaster. It was crowded, noisy, chaotic. And she had to ask me a series of questions that I could barely hear or understand. My poor exhausted, hormone-addled brain was afraid I'd done something wrong or was in trouble.
It was so loving, so compassionate, so appropriately personal. And she did it again today.

I was scared. I was angry. I didn't know what to do or say, and she had no way to help me. So what she said was, "It is gonna be ok. You are gonna be ok. I want to tell you, I have family members who have been through this. You will get through it too."

At one  point, mid way through chemo, when I was suffering from an intensely painful outbreak of hives, my insurance suddenly cut off pharmaceutical coverage. Turned out to be an administrative error on their part, but none of us knew that when our pharmacist had to tell us.
No one else has seen as many of my twists and turns as a patient than my pharmacist. And no one else has seen the emotions that come with those, the way my pharmacist has. Two examples:

I tweet a lot about how medical professionals often miss the mark when it comes to patient emotions. But there are other times when someone just absolutely stands out with their compassion and understanding. Let me tell you about my pharmacist.

From my perspective, while sometimes I can get overeager to share the cool stuff I think of, I generally think of my prep work as being an investment in the future of that game (or others). If the players don’t go that route, I adjust it or keep it for later.

@archmageofdice That makes sense. I do think that DnD can be done that way as well. But I think it's very hard to break out of that mold in that system, for a number of reasons. Since my early experiences of DnD really did break that mold, I have a skewed perspective on it.
It's really frustrating, when trying to run a game with genuine player choice, to have players reflexively searching for clues about what I want them to do next.
@MatthewCmiel I was thinking about it, and here's my main problem with too strongly emphasizing the "railroadiness" of DnD: It can become a self fulfilling prophecy.

@Molethulu @MatthewCmiel I like that metaphor! I do think that, a lot of the time, the defined stops can be less about the DM's vision and more about the logical outcomes of specific PC decisions given the world the DM (and sometimes also the PCs) have designed.

@MatthewCmiel I still think we should be honest that there is some direction that the DM needs brings to the narrative in DnD, especially at the beginning, moreso than with other games. I just think realizing that there are degrees of flexibility within that is important too.

@MatthewCmiel Second, I think in the best games, there's the outline of a story, but the meat of the actual narrative has to do with character arcs and relationships that the group builds onto that loose structure. What DnD is ultimately about isn't actually that outline of a story at all.
@MatthewCmiel For example, I never ever designate a bbeg that I intend my players to have a climactic battle with. They decide who is good/bad/other, and what needs to be done about it.

@MatthewCmiel I want to complicate that a little bit though, on two fronts. First, I think there are shades and degrees of "railroading," to the point that I don't think that metaphor works very well in a narrative where there are story threads but not exactly a fixed course.

@LBSamuelsson I share this, not at all to invalidate your feelings, because I've had them and still have them. I just felt compelled to shared that story with you, because I want you to feel loved the way I chose to love that part of myself in that moment. I wish that for you, so much.

@LBSamuelsson That doesn't always work. A lot of the time I still have waves and waves of loathing for this new body of mine. But some of the time - more and more - it gives me a sense of great freedom and hope. That I can enact in myself the many forms of love that I want to show others, too.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer Fair. I personally feel like the burden to listen should be tilted toward those of us with power and education in a given circumstance. When someone comes into my office complaining about "all therapists," I'd rather ask them how I can be different than tell them I already am.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer You being here and paying attention to these discussions is huge. And I know it's no small thing to be doing that on unpaid time. I wish more drs could do that, because often people speak much more frankly here than they would when they are fully in the role of patient.

@balinoruo @AdvocateRoma @ThanksCancer @VickyStanton09 @HEALEveryDay I don't think it's making it about us to notice that it's a problem for lots of folks. If staff really heard how hurtful it can be, they'd be able to do things like check in first, individually, about whether someone wants to do that, or consider having a less public ritual.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer When you hear "all doctors," as when I hear "all therapists," it's a signal that a systemic problem is being highlighted, and that our efforts to be individually better than that problem are not going to be sufficient. It needs to be addressed more broadly than that.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer Of course, we are all only speaking from our individual perspectives and will use hyperbole when we are passionate. But we are also in doing that speaking to general problems in the medical field, and I think that's the crucial piece.
@Dr_RShatsky @ThanksCancer @AmaliaSouthey Yep. Found out later that geriatrics is one of her specialties, so it sorta makes sense why she has this perspective. I just find it very unhelpful.

@balinoruo @AdvocateRoma @ThanksCancer @VickyStanton09 @HEALEveryDay I can definitely see it for pediatric patients, though a lot of kids and adolescents have complex feelings too and feel just as much pressure to put on a happy face as the rest of us. One-size-fits-all rituals seem really likely to be broadly ineffective to me.
@AdvocateRoma @VickyStanton09 @ThanksCancer @HEALEveryDay Just saw an article the other day about how parking fees are one of the things that are at the top of patient complaints about cancer care.

@balinoruo @AdvocateRoma @ThanksCancer @VickyStanton09 @HEALEveryDay What I want to know is, if this practice is so generally reviled (and I certainly hate it!), why is it still so broadly in use? What communication breakdown is happening that prevents staff from noticing how much patients hate it?

@VickyStanton09 @ThanksCancer @HEALEveryDay They played Pomp and Circumstance for me at the end of my chemo infusion schedule (I can't even bring myself to say "my last," because how would we ever know that for sure?), and I just kept thinking about all the people there listening who were going to be on chemo indefinitely.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer I belong to the profession probably the most complained about on Twitter, and there are times when I really REALLY want to jump in and say "but I'm not like that." But when I don't do that, I get to hear a lot more that actually helps me in my work.

@Dr_RShatsky @AmaliaSouthey @ThanksCancer No one likes to be generalized about, I get that. But there are good reasons why folks express frustration with doctors this way. Twitter gives us a chance to have these conversations more directly, with less of a power imbalance. That's a really good thing.

@ThanksCancer @AmaliaSouthey @Dr_RShatsky My dr has said to me "you're young, you'll bounce back" so many times, it drives me nuts. I think a lot of doctors are overworked and have never been challenged to examine their biases, so they aren't aware of how dismissive they actually are.

I just got an ad from continuing education company asking me the stunning question, "have you ever considered offering your services online?" Um. That is currently the default for my entire industry so ... yes?

@ThanksCancer @AmaliaSouthey @Dr_RShatsky My radiation-oncologist actually told me I was the only patient he had ever had who expressed a desire to get my radiation tattoos removed, and I think that says way more about him than it does about me.

@ThanksCancer @AmaliaSouthey @Dr_RShatsky I strongly suspect that many doctors have overly rosy outlooks about side effects because many patients don't want to complain, and the ones that do (especially female and/or POC ones) are often, consciously or unconsciously, dismissed instead of being listened to.

Celebrate with them; cheer them on. When they need that. But DO NOT STOP when the dramatic stuff, the stuff of movies and tv shows, has ended and they have to grapple with a lifetime of being touched by cancer.

If you have a cancer patient in your life, give them space for milestones to be a time of ambivalence, even fear. Understand that this disease is probably not what you think it is, and their experience may not be what you expect.

My family greeted me in the parking lot with balloons and flowers and cookies, and I am touched. It was so sweet! But I will need that kind of support for the rest of my life. It is an end for them. It is not an end for me.
I have in fact done work that should earn me a degree. But that work was self-education and self-advocacy. And that is not remotely over for me.
My radiation team gave me a full-seized 'diploma' (their word), and I am flabbergasted as to what I would even do with it. It says I have earned "degrees in courage and patience." This is bullshit.

So my feelings are complex. My family is (rightfully) celebratory. But I am cautious about celebrating what might not be my last time through this, and very aware that I am only starting a new leg of this experience. One that will get less attention and less support.

Only after 10 years, and maybe not even then, will my cancer be considered "cured." For now, it is only "in remission." Because my cancer spread to my lymphatic system, the likelihood that there are still cancer cells somewhere in my body is high.
I have 10 years of medication in front of me. And not pleasant easy don't-even-notice medication. Meds with side effects. And that's if I'm lucky, and the cancer does not return.
So, I finished radiation treatment today. Yay! From diagnosis, through surgery, chemo, and radiation, it's been 8 months of hard work. But ...

@JewishWonk Third, determination of unfitness is extremely rare and inconsistently applied. I was honestly shocked to see that a Black man was granted this determination. I can’t rule out that devaluation of the victims may have played a role, but the court’s finding really does make sense.

@JewishWonk Like substance abuse (also an illness and often developed as a desperate attempt at managing psychotic and mood symptoms). But there are rare cases where the illness and impaired judgment become extremely profound and violent on their own.

@JewishWonk For example, I have known people to become extremely paranoid about even their closest, safest family relationships. To be clear, the vast majority of people who experience psychosis are not dangerous! There are usually other factors contributing to it escalating this far.

@JewishWonk Second, you absolutely can formulate beliefs and engage in actions due to psychosis that would be utterly out of character and abhorrent to you otherwise. Maybe he had these beliefs and tendencies when not ill, but likely not.

@JewishWonk The result is that he will be in a (generally very unpleasant) mental health facility for an indeterminate and likely very, very long time without any of the same rights to appeal on his own behalf that he would have if convicted.

@JewishWonk Psychologist here. I don’t work with the courts, but I have worked a lot with psychotic disorders. Three things: first, ‘unfit to stand trial’ is about is about his ability to meaningfully understand and participate in his own defense, not his culpability for the crime.

I don’t always succeed, but when I can do this I find that I see the world and other people in it so much more clearly. I think more clearly. I am more present, because I am not lost in a labyrinth of thought designed to insulate me from the way I impact the world around me.

I aspire to do that when evaluating or being confronted by my own behaviors: focussing on the event in question and it’s concrete effects rather than comparing my choices to others’. It’s not easy, but for me it’s a practice that keeps me connected to truth, to feeling alive.

This is why I am always very cautious about addressing hypocrisy, even in people who I badly disagree with. If I can condemn something on its own terms rather than by comparing it to someone’s words or the behavior of others, I will do that instead.

Whataboutism isn’t just a rhetorical strategy, it’s a technique for eroding critical thought in yourself and others that tunes out the evidence of your senses and your conscience. That is why the very victims of the capital assault can now vote to acquit its orchestrator.

I'm lucky that this is so far the closest brush I have had with the chaos in our medical system. But I'm sharing it so that other folks will hear how this crisis trickles out into the community and threatens the lives of even the most cautious people.

There's no good way to describe how broken and dangerous the situation is here. I'm safe now, but knowing that I can't access the care I might need makes a situation that is otherwise very manageable feel fraught and infuriating.

This is the second time in 3 weeks that I have had an on-call doctor explain that the care I truly needed, for safety and comfort, was not advisable to me because of Covid. That my poor, scared wife would have to substitute for the medical professionals who would know what to do.

Where it went from scary to terrifying was when the doctor told us that, whereas normally he would send me to the ER to have it monitored, he couldn't advise that yet. Why? Because the ER would not be safe for me (given my compromised immune system) due to Covid.
Last night I had a spike of fever, a warning sign of a potentially very serious side effect of chemotherapy. It was scary. We called the on-call doctor as instructed.

@_raybird_ I have serious needle phobia and had to do injections for my beloved cat for many years. I found that focussing on soothing her rather than thinking about the needle helped to soothe me. I also did some deep breathing and reminding myself that it was safe.

I've experienced so much love and kindness in this year. To honor that, I try to measure 2020 in moments of blessing as well as moments of loss. Know that if you reached out to me in any way through any of this, you helped fill my 2020 with blessings.

I also feel proud that, sometimes, I made the choice to embrace who I am becoming because of the pain and fear and tragedy that entered my life. I couldn't always mange it, but as much as I could, I tried to walk through this year with hope for who it was calling me to be.
